values.comments:
Evaluators felt that Dr. Sil was a good to excellent professor, some saying he is among the best professors at Penn. Specific praise was mentioned for the clarity in his lectures, his ability to inspire students, his organization, and his ability to get students to fully and thoroughly understand course concepts. Many students remarked that despite the quality of the lectures and instructor, the amount of reading was overwhelming and that the readings became redundant.
*Note: Less than 25% of students submitted written evaluations for this class

Students had overwhelming praise for Dr. DiIulio, including many students stating that he is the best professor they have taken at Penn.  Evaluators noted that his passion for the material clearly shows and that he is genuinely excited about teaching it to students.  “Impressive” guest speakers were appreciated by the students.  Two major complaints were issued about the course.  The first was that the tests were strictly multiple choice and did not give students an opportunity to fully demonstrate their knowledge.  The second was that without a recitation students never had an opportunity to think critically and discuss/argue about course concepts.  
*Note:  Less than 25% of students submitted written evaluations for this class

Evaluators unanimously expressed praise for the course and for Dr. Summers’ vast knowledge of the material and teaching ability.  Students commended her for her accessibility, enthusiasm, and enlightening lectures.  Many students also gave high marks to the discussions in class, although a few students wished the class would be smaller.  Numerous evaluators mentioned that the community service aspect of the course was the most interesting and valuable part of the class.  As one student said, this course is “extremely applicable to anyone who eats.”

Students agreed that this was a “great” or “excellent” course, and praised Dr. Mansfield for his engaging lectures.
*Note: Less than 25% of students submitted written evaluations for this class

The evaluations for this course were extremely positive, praising Dr. Norton for her entertaining lecturing style and great teaching, leaving many students wishing Dr. Norton also taught a follow-up course. Numerous students claimed they would like to take more courses with Dr. Norton in the future, with one even saying Dr. Norton “may have changed my life.”
*Note: Less than 25% of students submitted written evaluations for this class

Students almost unanimously proclaimed this class to be an extraordinary educational experience, with numerous students stating that if “you really want to learn the material, take this course.”  Evaluations consistently said Dr. Weintraub truly cares about the students’ progression in the course and that he gives lots of feedback on all assignments.  Students did caution that classes generally run anywhere from 10 to 30 minutes over their designated time slot, although some students used this point to illustrate how much Dr. Weintraub cares about the material and the students’ understanding of it.

Students almost unanimously claimed Dr. Norton to be an “excellent professor,” although few specifics were given on her teaching style.
*Note: Less than 25% of students submitted written evaluations for this class

On the whole students found this class to be excellent and Dr. Kennedy’s teaching style to be engaging and entertaining.  Students found readings to be interesting, although some students felt that they were not always directly relevant to the lectures.

Students enjoyed the class, but felt that the second half of the course was substantially  more difficult than the first.  The readings were also said to have been more complex and abstract later in the course, although students did praise Dr. Ewasiuk’s ability to successfully convey course concepts during lecture.

Evaluators claimed that the course discussed interesting issues, but that lectures were a bit too repetitive and boring.  Nearly all students said they felt the course would be better with some refining.

Students very much enjoyed this class, calling it “insightful” and “intellectually stimulating.”  While students said it was among the more challenging courses they have taken, more than one felt it was among Penn’s best courses.
Students found this course to be quite good, and also praising Dr. Amyx for being very knowledgeable and accessible outside of class time.

Students thought Dr. Lombera was very good at motivating students and stimulating enlightening discussion.  Different students liked and disliked specific parts of this course.  For example, the course placed a strong emphasis on the historical background, which was both a pro and con in different students’ minds.

Evaluators had near unanimous praise for Dr. Goldstein, citing the information covered in the class, the organization of the lectures, and the efficiency of the lectures.  The complaints that were expressed centered primarily on the TAs and recitations, although some also expressed a desire for Dr. Goldstein to slow down the pace of lectures.
Students felt that the course was a disappointment overall, saying the material was not very stimulating and that lectures were not well prepared or delivered.

Students found this class both very interesting and also filled with very practical knowledge.  They praised Dr. Norris’s teaching style and felt the course would be far more valuable to the average Penn student than many mandatory introductory classes.

Students seem to have enjoyed this class, with most students calling both the course and professor “great” or “excellent.”  Evaluators said the course was well designed, with field trips and guest speakers being positive additions.

values.comments: Kettl was described as a “truly excellent professor,” and apparently has excellent speaking and presentation skills as well although some students did not appreciate his digressions in class. Some people also did not like the lectures, saying that they were “useless” because all the information was on the slide, but recitation was well appreciated. The course material seemed to be of interest to many: “A good overview of American politics for a beginner s that doesn’t discourage newcomers by presenting hard to follow topics.”  “Highly recommended to everyone!” raves one student.

Professor Mansfield was described as being both “vain and irrelevant” as well as “a bit personally aloof, but did a great job of communicating the material.” Students passionately disapproved of the tests for the course, which were apparently “unreasonable, given the time constraints in which they were given” according to one student. Students wished for a bit more interaction, and examples that tied into the readings more. One student described the class as “a great introduction to the poli-sci department.”

Virtually all the student reviews complained that Professor Shiffman was very quiet, difficult to hear throughout his lectures. However, it appears that he improved on that progressively during the semester. Organization was not one of the professor’s strong points. Students loved many of the readings, but said that the book was rather expensive considering how many pages the professor actually assigned. Some students loved the material, saying “this was the type of class I came to college for” and that it “taught me a lot not only in terms of academics but also in terms of life in general.”

values.comments:
This course is an introduction to comparative political analysis, with a focus on themes including the role of the state, democracy and dictatorship, economic reforms and revolutions.
 Most students either really loved or really hated this course; it ranged from a “must-take” to “worst course” at Penn. Fans sung the praises of its “novel approach” to comparative politics, which centered around five books that illustrate different concepts. These students felt the class effectively equipped them with new perspectives and ways of critically analyzing politics, calling it “extremely worthwhile and thought-provoking.” One enthusiastic student said the course was “so rich and extensive” that it made students “almost dizzy with new knowledge.” On the other end of the spectrum, students felt the course was disorganized, dull, and difficult to follow. Critics of the reading-centered approach said the course lacked a central purpose or structure, and they complained about a disjointed focus on small, scattered details rather than a comprehensive grasp on the subject. Many noted that the course could be improved with clearer direction and less information-dense lecture slides.   
These stratified assessments of the course often boil down to opinions of Professor Lustick himself. Though almost all students praised Professor Lustick’s intellect, some criticized how he presented information, such as in “highly esoteric and jargon-filled” lectures and confusing diagrams. While some students called his lectures dull and dense, others praised his passion and ability to break down complex theories.
  This is one of six Political Science core course options for majors; participants ranged from those with their first PSCI course to those with many under their belt. Students generally found the course a challenge. Many found the readings and lectures more complex, theoretical and dense than they expected of an introductory level class. They also said there was a lot of work, in large part because of the reading assignments. Assignments include a paper, midterm and final. Said one student, “with a name like ‘Introduction to Comparative Politics,’ I was hoping to grasp the topics at hand more formidably.”

section.name: SELECTED TOPICS: Neoliberalism and the Global Justice Movement

values.comments:
Everyday human behavior poses puzzles that political scientists, economists, sociologists, and other social scientists have attempted to answer. Often their respective answers or "theories" differ widely; and sometimes even their most widely agreed-upon answers seem to defy common sense or ask us to believe in highly improbable findings. This new lecture course familiarizes students with different approaches to understanding politics, society, and social science in relation to everyday questions, intriguing puzzles, and improbable findings about human behavior. It focuses on contemporary American politics and society, and draws mainly on literatures featuring work by leading U.S. social scientists. In addition, the course explores the conceptual boundaries between the political, social, and economic domains in which people interact with one another; the differences among and between different much-acclaimed models for understanding human behavior; and the philosophical underpinnings and moral implications associated with schools of thought about how best to describe, analyze, and evaluate what people do--and why they do it!

Students stated that this course was “a good introduction to the social science field” and “presented both points of view, asking the student to take a stand and think outside the box". Some students complained of excessive reading material and of a lack of variety as, "almost every single reading" was "authored by the Professor" or "quoted him". However, the majority of students ultimately concluded that they came away from the course with an interesting point of view.

Students for the most part praised Professor DiIullio for his “amazing ability to summarize complex material and explain in ways that illuminate your understanding of the topic”. One student declared, "I quickly learned that whatever comes out of Professor DiIullio's mouth is worth listening to, and worth sticking around for". Although some students critiqued Professor DiIullio for too much "formal presentation that was two hours straight" of "pre-typed paragraphs of notes" and "no power points," the majority of students lauded the Professor for his "outspoken" and "engaging" manner.   

 Many of the students in this course stated that although the exams were difficult, they would recommend this course to all students, especially political science majors. However, one student stated that Professor DiIullio was very unclear when it came to what material to study and review for tests and that \"it was a guessing game as to what he would test you on and the exams rarely were an accurate representation of what he emphasized in class\". One student stated that the decision to use multiple choice instead of short essay format for exams was \"inappropriate given the wide range of interesting topics that we covered throughout the semester\". Many students also complained about the \"unnecessary\" and \"time-consuming\" recitation memos that were due at the beginning of each week.

section.name: Inside/Out: The Politics of Crime and Punishment
International Relations in Theory and Practice

values.comments:
This course is designed to help student learn about constitutional theory, present-day political institutions, and ever evolving federal character, electoral processes, and policy-making dynamics of American government. Some of the fundamental questions that this class grapples with are: what are the historical and philosophical foundations of the American Republic; how does American public policy get made, who makes it, and who benefits; is a constitutional fabric woven in 1787 good enough for today; and what is politics and why bother to study it? Readings include The Federalist Papers, “The Wilson Text,” “The Bose Reader,” Get Out the Vote: How to Increase Voter Turnout, and Politics Lost: How American Democracy was Trivialized by People Who Think You’re Stupid. 

Many students found this class “interesting” and a great introductory class. One student even claimed he/she believed this class should be a college requirement because “though concepts are probably basic from the perspective of a political scientist, it would be a good thing for our country if more people understood even these basic concepts.” 

Students highly praised Professor DiIulio – they commonly reported he was “engaging,” “had good stories,” and “entertaining;” many students claimed Professor DiIulio was one of the best teachers they have ever had. Students also said that Professor DiIulio was very accessible and able to stimulate interest in the material very well. 

This course fulfills the Society sector and is highly recommended for freshmen considering a Political Science or another humanities major. Many students complained about the somewhat excessive amounts of reading. While some students found the exams to be challenging and heavily focused on the readings, the majority of students believed that it was a fairly easy introductory class.

While this course evaluates how power is distributed among diverse leaders in government, business, nonprofit organizations, and other sectors, it also focuses on leadership on a personal level and encourages students to assess their own leadership skills in self-assessment tests. Students assess the concept of leadership’s historical significance and popular usages; assess competing "leadership theories," empirical as well as normative; examine assorted claims about leadership "best practices" in different U.S. sectors (government, business, nonprofit). 

Students really enjoyed this class as they found the lectures and readings to be “captivating” and “engaging”. Students really liked that the class forced “introspection,” claiming that they learned a lot about themselves. Many students claimed it was the best class they had every taken. One student explained, “while you may not learn ‘real world skills,’ I learned some far more valuable things about myself.”

Most students were very impressed that Professor DiIulio made time for his students outside of class and found it useful to have him as a recitation instructor. One student said, “Dr. DiIulio was able to spark interest in subjects that would otherwise seem somewhat boring,” and another declared, “Unlike most famous or brilliant professors, he actually cares for his students, and will make the effort to ensure you get the most out of the course.”

There are no prerequisites for this class, and it is recommended for both majors and non-majors. Some found the workload to be challenging in terms of length of reading and writing assignments required, but overall, students really enjoyed the class.

section.name: Power in American Society: Leadership & Democracy

values.comments:
This course is an introduction to the major theories and issues in international politics. The goals of the course are to give students a broad familiarity with the field of international relations, and to help them develop the analytical skills necessary to think critically about international politics. The course is divided into four parts: 1) Concepts and Theories of International Relations; 2) War and Security; 3) The Global Economy; and 4) Emerging Issues in International Relations. 

Many students said that the class helped them gain a firm foundation for future International Relations classes. Students thought that the class was well organized, but found the lectures to be occasionally somewhat dry. 

Students praised Professor Stanton for being very accessible and friendly. Students thought Professor Stanton’s lectures were very well planned and thought that “her enthusiasm for teaching the class showed;” however, at times, the lectures were “too rehearsed.” One student praised Professor Stanton for her ability to relate lecture material to assigned readings. 

This class fulfills the Society requirement and is a good introductory class for students interested in International Relations. Though some students found there to be too much reading, most students found the workload to be manageable. Students complained about the harshness of the grading curve for an introductory course and thought tests and papers were graded “very strictly”.

The course evaluates the strategy and politics of warfare, focusing on the way actors plan military campaigns and the factors that are likely to lead to victory and defeat. The course readings center in particular on the factors driving changes in warfare and civil-military relations. Specifically, the course attempts to use theories of warfare drawn from political science to shed light on key battles, campaigns, and military outcomes. There is a good deal of reading for the course and the lectures will make a lot more sense if you keep up with the reading for each week. Readings include Clausewitz, Carl von, On War, Counterinsurgency Warfare: Theory and Practice, The First World War, The Second World War, and Eagle Against the Sun: The American War With Japan The Art of War

Most students found this course to be “absolutely fascinating” and thought the lectures went by very quickly. They found that they learned a lot and gained a unique perspective on the subject matter.

Students really enjoyed having Professor Horowitz as their lecturer. One student said, “I am incredibly impressed, lecture after lecture by how much information Professor Horowitz is able to clearly communicate to us in so short a period [of time].” Another student claimed that Professor Horowitz was “both funny and engaging in the way he talked about the material.” Students found Professor Horowitz to be very accessible as well. 

This course presumes that you have a general knowledge of modern European history, but there are no formal course prerequisites. Most students found the course to be very challenging and thought that the lectures were fast-paced. Students complained about the abundance of reading, which averaged 350 pages a week and sometimes peaked at 750 pages. However, students found the exam format to be fair and believed that it was helpful to have a list of IDs covered on the exams.

This course explores the role of constitutional principles and the U.S. Supreme Court in political struggles over the structure, distribution and uses of power in the American political system. Emphasis is placed on division of powers between the state and national governments and the branches of the federal government; economic powers of private actors and governmental regulators; and authority over national security issues. In analyzing governmental structures and powers, the course also focuses on the substantive values the American constitutional system has pursued in the hands of different political coalitions over time, and on the virtues and vices of constitutionalism as the mode of their pursuit. Most readings come from the new constitutional law casebook, American Constitutionalism, Vol. 1, Structures of Government, by Howard Gillman, Mark A. Graber, and Keith E. Whittington. 

Though students found the class to be very interesting, the main complaint students had was that there was little connection between assigned readings and course content; many found the reading to be “not terribly cohesive.” 

Students raved about Professor Smith, claiming he “is a master in his field” and “a superb lecturer” with a good sense of humor. They found Professor Smith to be knowledgeable and exceedingly good at stimulating interest in the material. The one complaint that students had was that his Powerpoint slides were not very informative. 

Students found the reading exceedingly long, dense, and challenging, but one student said, “exams and papers were fair and interesting to answer.” The class is strongly recommended for majors. Many students found it to be quite challenging.

section.name: The Politics of Government in Washington Community
The Idea of Development: Past, Present and Future
POL,CULTURE&AMER. CITIES: Politics, Culture and American Cities
JUDICIAL POWER: Judicial Power: Empirical and Normative Issues in Comparative Politics

values.comments:
This course is an opportunity for students to combine the major theoretical perspectives on the policy process with practical application to current policy issues. Students will gain the theoretical tools to explain policy change, a comprehensive understanding of the actors that influence policymaking and politics, an overview of the major policy issues being debated, and experience writing policy documents.

Most students found this course “interesting” and commented that they “learned a lot.” Students especially liked the “practical, real-world applications.” However, many students also felt the material or presentation of it was “dry and boring.”

Students differed in their opinion of Professor Gasper. Some stated he was an “okay professor” while others thought that he was “interesting and enthusiastic.” Many students blamed the dryness of the class on the course material and believed Professor Gasper was not to blame for the “mundane subject matter.” Students agreed that Professor Gasper was “clear,” “easily understood,” and conveyed the material well. Students also appreciated Professor Gasper’s accessibility via e-mail and his attempt to start discussion in the 100+ person class.

Many students took the course because it is a requirement for PPE majors. One student commented that the course was “not a lot of work, but not as easy as it should be.” Most were disappointed with the recitations led by undergrad TAs and thought it was a “waste of time.”

section.name: THE PUBLIC POL PROCESS: The Public Policy Process

values.comments:
In this course, students will study the strategies of running for public office and evaluate how finance and fundraising, demographics, party organization, affect election outcomes. Many assignments will focus on analyzing campaign case studies and even ask students to evaluate the career of Professor Rendell himself. Students will have the opportunity to hear influential speakers as well. 

For the most part, student found the class “engaging.” They found the speakers very interesting; however, some complained that the class lacked structure. One student said, “Every student should take this course.” 

Students really enjoyed having Governor Rendell as a professor. One student proclaimed, “Governor Rendell is a wonderful storyteller and is able to invite high impact guests and campaign veterans.” Students said that Governor Rendell was a fascinating and very knowledgeable lecturer. 

This class is highly recommended for both majors and non-majors, but students complained that the final project was very time consuming and that much of the assignments and work tended to pile up near the end of the semester.

WRITING SEMINAR IN PSCI: MOBILES AND MOBILIZATION

RESISTING GLOBALIZATION: Globalization and the Global Justice Movement: Contesting Neoliberalism

WRITING SEMINAR IN PSCI: RHETORIC OF PRESIDENCY

values.comments:
This course analyzes the formation and conduct of foreign policy in the United States. The course combines three elements: a study of the history of American foreign relations; an analysis of the causes of American foreign policy such as the international system, public opinion, and the media; and a discussion of the major policy issues in contemporary U.S. foreign policy, including terrorism, civil wars, and economic policy.

Students for the most part enjoyed the content of the course, with many saying it was “the best class” they had taken at Penn. Students emphasized that “they learned a lot” and many indicated that the course had “stimulated interest” in political science. Most students found the lectures “straightforward” and “easy to follow.”

Students heaped praise on Professor Tierney, nearly unanimously calling him an “excellent lecturer,” a “charismatic and engaging professor” and stating that “Professor Tierney has a true talent for teaching.” Students also stressed that Professor Tierney was available to help his students.

Students complained that there was too much reading but each was nicely explained in class.  The course is highly recommended for majors and non-majors alike.

section.name: POLICYMAKING IN AMER POL: Policy-Making in American Politics

values.comments:
This lecture course introduces students to the subfield of international security or strategic studies. In order to grasp the usefulness of the theoretical ideas presented in readings and lectures, abstract concepts are linked with a study of the national security policies states have adopted in the decades following World War II. Topics include the fundamental distinctions among the alternative strategies available to states, the various strategies the U.S. and other countries have adopted, the links between military forces and strategy, the lessons one might draw from the history of international security relations during the Cold War, and the new sources of conflict and the prospects for continued international peace in the post-Cold War world.

Students thoroughly enjoyed this class and found it highly interesting. Many reported learning a lot and felt that each class covered a significant amount of information. While students appreciated the overall structure of the course, some noted that they “wish there was more integration of current events” and others believed that the material became mildly repetitive at certain points during the semester.  Countless students declared that this was the best class they have taken at Penn.

Students regarded Professor Goldstein as being “fantastic, engaging and magical.” They enjoyed his teaching style, organization and communication skills, although a few noted that Professor Goldstein talks too quickly at times. Most agreed that “Professor Goldstein brings an exciting atmosphere to lecture that makes it worthwhile to attend,” and many looked forward to taking another class of his in upcoming semesters. 

Some were overwhelmed by the amount of assigned reading each week and found the midterm to be a bit long. However, the majority believed that it was well worth it to take this course. Students commented that both Political Science majors and non-majors would benefit from taking this class.

section.name: Neoliberalism and the Global Justice Movement

values.comments:
Contemporary South Asian Politics is cross-listed as PSCI220 and SAST223. The course focuses on contemporary politics in India and Pakistan. The greater part of the course analyzes the social and political dynamics of democracy in India, but the material is also relevant to better understanding the difficulties encountered by Pakistan in defining a core identity and a stable form of government.

Overall, students enjoyed this class calling it “a joy to take” and “very informative.” They also liked how Professor Frankel integrated films, readings, and lectures to give students a better understanding of the subject. However, students did have grievances with the class structure and content, saying they wished the class would also include information on other South Asian countries.   “A course on contemporary South Asian politics should not ignore the larger dynamics of the region,” said one student. 

Students liked Professor Frankel, commenting that it was “a privilege to learn from such a renowned professor” and that she was always “very helpful during office hours.” However they wished she had given better feedback on paper topics.

Students found the hardest part of the course were the papers as the assigned subject was often very broad and it was hard to know what the professor was looking for. They also mentioned that there were too many assigned readings and that it was difficult to keep up with the pace of the class. “At a certain point the value of so many readings greatly diminishes and becomes incredibly difficult to analyze and comprehend.” Students commented that there was not enough time between paper assignments, as papers were not handed back before the next one was due.

The greater part of the course analyzes the social and political dynamics of democracy in India, but the material is also relevant to better understanding the difficulties encountered by Pakistan in defining a core identity and a stable form of government.

Overall, students enjoyed this class calling it “a joy to take” and “very informative.” They also liked how Professor Frankel integrated films, readings, and lectures to give students a better understanding of the subject. However, students did have grievances with the class structure and content, saying they wished the class would also include information on other South Asian countries.   “A course on contemporary South Asian politics should not ignore the larger dynamics of the region,” said one student.

Students found the hardest part of the course were the papers as the assigned subject was often very broad and it was hard to know what the professor was looking for. They also mentioned that there were too many assigned readings and that it was difficult to keep up with the pace of the class. “At a certain point the value of so many readings greatly diminishes and becomes incredibly difficult to analyze and comprehend.” Students commented that there was not enough time between paper assignments, as papers were not handed back before the next one was due.

section.name: NEW WRLD ORDER & CRITICS: WSP: New World Order and its Critics
POL ECON OF MODERN INDIA: Political Economy of Modern India
Democracy and Markets in Postcommunist Europe
International Relations in Theory and Practice
Ancient Greek Political Thought: Past and Present

values.comments: This course is designed to introduce students to comparative political analysis. The course covers how political behavior, circumstances, institutions, and dynamic patterns of change that people experience in very different societies can be analyzed using the same set of concepts and theories. Key themes include nationalism, political culture, democratization, authoritarianism, and the nature of protracted conflict.   All the materials taught in the class were “relevant” and “controversial”. Students were encouraged to think outside of the box. The class focused on comparing between Israel and South Africa and was able to stimulate an interesting discussion.    There are mixed comments for Professor Vitalis. Some students thought the professor was “intellectually demanding” and “provocative”. The class is taught in a seminar style to a class of over 100 people. As such, some students thought the class was very disorganized and Professor Vitalis did not come with a prepared set of notes. Students that enjoyed the class learned a lot from the discussions.    There are no quizzes, homework assignments, tests nor midterms for the class. Students read 5 books and wrote book reports. The class format did not allow for any lazy academic work. Nothing is spoon-fed and students explored real political science subjects.

This course is concerned with the political character of contemporary urban American life. During the semester students will be familiar with the structural and ideological factors that constrain the policy context and define the urban environment as a terrain for commingling, competition and conflict over uses of space. The goal of this course is to throw into relief the complex and sometimes subtle processes that have shaped and continue to shape urban life in the United States.   Many of the students enjoyed this course with a majority stating that, “required readings were extremely interesting.” The only complaint of the class was that, “…very little seemed to ever get accomplished in class.” Those that recommended the course wrote comments such as: “…exploration of a topic most would not ever consider studying.”  Most students that reviewed the course reviewed Professor Read as preforming well as a professor. The majority of complaints commented that the professor was, “…not able to effectively communicate the subject matter.” Students did say that professor Read was willing to meet with students.  This course is not listed as fulfilling any major college requirements. In addition, there are no prerequisites listed. Grading for the course is broken up into class participation, two take home exams, a midterm, and a final. The course is open to both freshmen and upperclassmen.

This course is an introduction to the major theories and issues in international politics. The goals of the course are to give students a broad familiarity with the field of international relations, and to help them develop the analytical skills necessary to think critically about international politics. The course is divided into four parts: 1) Concepts and Theories of International Relations; 2) War and Security; 3) The Global Economy; and 4) Emerging Issues in International Relations.   Most students reported loving this “fascinating” course. According to one student, “the class was so good that I always looked forward to it even though it was three hours on Monday nights,” and another commented: “I wish I had taken this class earlier…as I feel like I could have wanted to take more political science classes.” Another described class discussions as “deep, engaging and though-provoking.” Students generally reported learning a lot from the course; however, one student found the readings to be “too boring and lengthy to complete.”    Students enthusiastically praised Dr. Doherty-Sil, describing her as “phenomenal” and “the best lecturer I have ever had.” Students agreed that she was extremely “passionate” and energetic and also “very knowledgeable” in her field. Students found her to be an effective communicator of the material and always available for questions. One student found her passion off-putting, commenting that it bordered on “eccentric” and was “hard to keep pace with.”   This class fulfills the Society Sector and was well-received by both political science majors and non-majors. According to one student, the course “did not require much work.”   **Class only reviewed by 6 students.

This lecture course introduces students to the subfield of international security or strategic studies. In order to grasp the usefulness of the theoretical ideas presented in readings and lectures, abstract concepts are linked with a study of the national security policies states have adopted in the decades following World War II. Topics include current debates about nuclear proliferation, terrorism, the Iraq war, Europe's changing international role, the rise of China, Asian "flashpoints" (Korea, the Taiwan Strait), and US security policy for the 21st century - considering some of the main strategic alternatives to the US as well as their implications for the types of forces deployed (the impact of the "revolution in military affairs," the future of missile defense, and the economic burden to be shouldered).    Many students felt that the course material was extremely interesting, although a few noted that it could be “repetitive”. One student summarized the class, saying “the first half of the class focused on the theoretical essentials of international security (e.g., deterrence) and the latter half on specific issues.”    Most students raved about Professor Goldstein as an extremely intelligent, funny, and dedicated professor. One student commented: “His ability to convey his advanced ideas in a way that students understand and to simultaneously challenge us to think individually about the course's topics made his a wonderful asset as a teacher.” The one major complaint was that he was a quick lecturer, going through material at a rapid pace.    This course was described as reading heavy and many students commented on the tough grading.

This course examines the politics of international economic relations. Material covered during the semester includes analysis of the interplay between politics and economics in international trade, international finance, and economic development.  Students wrote that the course was “informative”. Additionally, some students commented that the readings were quite interesting, yet in some cases lengthy. Many students wrote that they found the class to be “useful” and one of the best they had taken at Penn.  Students praised Professor Pollack’s teaching style. Many said that he was the best professor that they have had at Penn. Students found his lectures to be “stimulating,” “valuable,” and “well-organized”. Additionally students wrote that Professor Pollack was able to communicate the material in a clear and engaging way.  This course is not listed as fulfilling any major college requirements. In addition, there are no prerequisites listed. The course is open to both college freshmen and upperclassmen. Many students wrote that they would recommend this class to majors and non-majors.

This course provides an overview of major figures and themes of modern political thought. It focuses on themes and questions pertinent to political theory in the modern era, particularly focusing on the relationship of the individual to community, society, and state. Although the emergence of the individual as a central moral, political, and conceptual category arguably began in earlier eras, it is in the seventeenth century that it takes firm hold in defining the state, political institutions, moral thinking, and social relations. The centrality of "the individual" has created difficulties, even paradoxes, for community and social relations, and political theorists have struggled to reconcile those throughout the modern era. This course considers the political forms that emerged out of those struggles, as well as the changed and distinctly "modern" conceptualizations of political theory such as freedom, responsibility, justice, rights and obligations, as central categories for organizing moral and political life.  Students found the course to be difficult, especially due to the confusing readings. Students did find that the course opened up their minds to think about complex ideas in new ways, thus improving their critical thinking skills. Due to the lack of visual aids in lecture and the unfocused prompts for class writing, many students said they would have liked to see more structure within the course.   Professor Hirschmann has an obvious enthusiasm for the subject and for her students. She is very accessible by appointment or by email and is always willing to discuss something that a student does not understand. She was able to stimulate interest in lecture, even when the material got flat.   The majority of students liked this course, but many said that it was difficult to know what material was the most relevant for tests and papers. Professor Hirschmann allows students to take home exams but the grading is tough. Students generally would recommend this course, but only to a major or someone highly interested in this field.

This course examines the major influences and contributions to political thought from 1900 to the present. This course discusses the nature of politics, appraises liberal democracy, and explores the problem of emergency powers. Students will study works from authors such as Weber, Arendt, Dewey, Berlin, Habermas, Rawls, Foucault, and Derrida.  Students praised the course content while warning that the material can be challenging. Students agreed that, “the readings are very complex.” Even though the course includes works by, “complex political philosophers,” students found that each was thoroughly explained and analyzed. Some students cautioned, however that, “the amount of reading was difficult to keep up with.”  Professor Green received overwhelmingly positive feedback from students. One student described Professor Green as, “a brilliant man who brings passionate intensity to his course material.” Students were impressed with how willing Professor Green was to remain after class to field questions and clarifications. Students were likewise appreciative that Professor Green provided lecture notes before classes as an aid.  Students in this course recommended that future students have an interest in political philosophy if they wish to gain the most from this course. The course is open to both college freshmen and upperclassmen.

A seminar in which recent topics have been The Analysis of Presidential Elections, Conservative Political Economy, and Political Geography.  The course material changes due to the fact that this class is a seminar. The material covered this semester included "human rights" and "international law." Students generally enjoyed the class and found the course material "interesting.'   The people who took this class were all pleased with having Dr. Fetni as a professor. One students said, "Dr. Fetni is clearly very knowledgeable and has a lot of very interesting insights events." Another students said, "He wants all students to succeed and will help anyone to achieve their goals." Students also commended Dr. Fetni for doing "an extremely good job of making the course relevant to what is going on currently in the world." Students found Dr. Fetni easily to contact and communicate with.   The bulk of the work is discussion in class and the readings. Students should be prepared to doing do "lengthy" reading.

section.name: America in Context / Contemporary Issues in American Politics

values.comments: This course covers the influence of money in politics, the cause of suicide terrorism, and police discriminiation against racial minorities. The course tries to explain political questions taken from international relations, American politics, comparative politics, and public policy. Students will learn how to construct research designs to test hypotheses and analyze the political world.   Students unanimously raved about this course. Several called it the, “best” or, “most important” class they had taken at Penn. One student claimed that it, “teaches undergrads how to think, not just what to think,” while another felt it was, “an essential class for anyone looking to do social science research.”  Reviews of Professor Malhotra were exclusively positive. Students called him “brilliant,” “fascinating,” and, “always available.”  Students commented that “the reading load is extremely light” and “participation is constant.” Several recommended this class to anyone interested in social sciences. The course is open to both freshmen and upperclassmen.

This course is an introduction to the most prominent historical, cultural, institutional, and ideological features of Middle Eastern politics. Typical questions addressed are, amongst others, why processes of modernization and economic change have not produced liberal democracies and why Islamic movements have gained enormous strength in some countries and not others.   Materials in class were learned through independent reading rather than lectures. Students are expected to read 200 pages of history independently while working on the research paper.     Professor Lustick has high expectations for his students. Students gained a lot from this class and thought Professor Lustick is “excellent” and “enthusiastic”. Even though the readings are very extensive, students felt that they learned a lot from the readings though the Professor was sometimes unclear which readings corresponded to which lecture.     Some students thought that the work-load was too extensive and the class seem to be geared toward upperclassmen with more experience.

section.name: THE EUROPEAN UNION: The European Union: Arguments and Evidence

values.comments: This course introduces students to the nation's trillion-dollar tax-exempt sector with a focus on religious nonprofit organizations including congregations and other so-called faith-based institutions. Topics discussed during the semester include new and old questions surrounding church-state relations, the role of religion in American politics, empirical "faith factor" research, and attempts to estimate the social costs and benefits associated with diverse religious nonprofit organizations.  Most students enjoyed this course citing the professor as the main cause. Those that wrote negative reviews of the course commented on the large amount of group work. One student wrote, “There were too many task group presentations, which created a moral hazard.”   The majority of students wrote excellent reviews of Professor Diiulio. A student wrote that the professor was an, “excellent instructor who consistently conveys the material in a way that allows you to understand how to apply it in a manner in which you can be of service to others.” Students were excited to learn from Professor Diiulio.   This course is not listed as fulfilling any major college requirements. In addition, there are no prerequisites listed. The course is open to both freshmen and upperclassmen.

section.name: INTL REL OF US & ASIA:  In'tl Rel of US&Asia

values.comments: This Fox Leadership and academically based community service seminar uses course readings and students’ own observations and interviews in their service learning projects in West Philadelphia schools to analyze the causes and impact of school health and educational inequalities and efforts to address them. Course readings include texts by Jonathan Kozol, studies of health inequalities and their causes, and studies of No Child Left Behind, the CDC’s School Health Index, recess, school meal, and nutrition education programs. Course speakers help students examine the history, theories, politics and leadership behind different strategies for addressing school-based inequalities and their outcomes. Service options focus especially on the West Philadelphia Recess Initiative. Other service options include work with Community School Student Partnerships and the Urban Nutrition Initiative. Students write several short papers based on course readings and present group reports and case studies based on the service projects. (A research paper is optional.)    Students generally enjoyed this course, and one student called it “one of my favorite classes at Penn.” The service placement was the “central component” of the course, which one student described as “truly hands-on learning.” The focus certainly seemed to be on students’ placements, and one student commented that sometimes class discussion dwelt too much “on anecdotes from service placements” that didn’t necessarily contribute substantially to their understanding of greater issues in education. A couple of students found the class “a little too large for a seminar” and thought the course would have functioned better with fewer students.    Students described Professor Summers very positively, describing her as “excellent,” “incredibly sweet,” and “truly passionate” about improving urban schools. Students also found Professor Summers to be extremely “flexible” and “understanding” when it came to making adjustments to assignments and coursework. Professor Summers was genuinely interested in hearing about students’ experiences with their placements and was dedicated to helping students do well on their projects. A few students mentioned that a little more organization and direction of class discussions would have been beneficial.    Students described this ABCS course as a good course for students interested in service learning, urban environments, schools, and politics. One student noted that it was a “great introduction to a service learning class.”  **Class only reviewed by 6 students

section.name: Business and Politics in Latin America

values.comments: This course integrates economic, ethical and political perspectives. It examines competing theories, models, and analytical frameworks for understanding policymaking. The course will focus on how public problems are framed and described, the criteria are useful in developing and assessing policy choices, and how policy choices and outcomes are mediated and influenced by individuals, organizations and political institutions.  Students had mixed feelings about the material taught. Many felt that one needed a "basic understanding for American politics" to follow the lectures. Some found the material "interesting."  Some students claimed that Professor Lapinski’s lectures, "were rushed" and "Professor Lapinski is obviously very knowledgeable about public policy, but he has some trouble organizing his thoughts during lecture."  The prerequisite for this course is ECON001. Work for the course includes about 100-200 pages of reading every week along with a weekly one page response. There is also a 20 page research paper due during the semester. This is class is recommended for majors only and is a requirement of the PPE major.

section.name: THE PUBLIC POL. PROCESS: The Public Policy Process
Overcoming Obstacles to Democracy in America

values.comments:
This course is intended to introduce students to the national institutions and political processes of American government: the historical and philosophical foundations of the American Republic: the significance of politics; how American public policy is made, who makes it, and who benefits; the modern application of the constitutional fabric woven in 1787; how, if at all, should American government be changed. 

Overall, students felt generally positive about the course material, calling the class “thought-provoking” and “valuable.” One student wrote that it was “a perfect starting point for anyone interested in American politics.” Several, however, expressed their dissatisfaction that the course did not live up to their high expectations. “This class is a lot of hype,” wrote one student, calling the lectures “forgettable.” Many complained that “the two-hour lecture was too long” to hold their attention, despite their interest in the material.

Reactions to Professor DiIulio were overwhelmingly positive. Students called him “inspiring,” “extremely powerful,” and “a phenomenal lecturer.” Several proclaimed him “the best professor I’ve had at Penn.”

Many students found the amount of reading required for this course “unreasonable” and the extra-credit policy “horribly unfair.” Most recognized that “this course is designed for freshmen and sophomores,” which some found “constricting,” and felt led to “too much hand-holding” on the part of the TAs. Despite these observations, many students recommended this class to majors and non-majors alike.

This academically based community service seminar explores the politics and institutions that have shaped—and continue to shape—food production and consumption. Students use the readings, their community service, and ongoing "food events" at Penn to analyze the politics of food in many arenas: from farms, kitchens, supermarkets, schools, and communities of faith to corporations, research institutions, the media and international trade.

Overall, students felt this class was “interesting” and “amazing.” Some felt that the three-hour seminar could be “boring,” and that time in class was not utilized effectively. Others thought that the community service aspect of the course unevenly burdened the students, as “the amount of time required on the part of the student varied dramatically” between projects.

Students had uniformly positive reviews of Professor Summers, calling her “extremely passionate,” “engaging,” and “one of the most effective instructors I’ve had at Penn.”

Some students found the workload somewhat difficult to manage because they were expected to read “about one book a week,” and complete “lots of little papers and assignments.” Many, however, were quick to recommend this course to their peers, with one student calling it “the most rewarding class I’ve taken so far.”

This course is an introduction to the major theories and issues in international politics. The goals of the course are to give students a broad familiarity with the field of international relations, and to help them develop the analytical skills necessary to think critically about international politics. The course is divided into four parts: 1) Concepts and Theories of International Relations; 2) War and Security; 3) The Global Economy; and 4) Emerging Issues in International Relations. Each topic is explored through course readings and applications.

Students tended to use the word “average” or “typical” in describing this course. Students felt nothing was explored thoroughly, as the course aimed to cover a large range of subjects. 

Professor Stanton was well liked by the students, praised for her ability to communicate the material and to inspire interest in students. However, she was thought to be “inaccessibly beyond the TAs.” This may have been due to the TAs being the main determiners of grades, but the Professor often would just refer students to their respective TA. Comments regarding the teaching technique and effectiveness seemed to be divided. Some said the lectures were interesting and connected the material well to the outside world, while others said they could tell the professor was young and still hadn’t mastered her teaching style.  

The class is heavily lecture based and though the textbook was said to be incredibly boring, the extra readings were reported to be interesting and thought to enhance the learning within the course by applying theory and material to current events. The readings overlapped heavily with lecture material so many students felt that the course got a little repetitive. One main complaint of students was the fact that the TAs were relied upon heavily for discussion, grading and questions. Students felt that in preparation for tests this gave some recitation sections an advantage. Therefore, comments ranged from “my favorite course of the semester” to “nothing interesting.” Many but not all of the students that took this course were Political Science majors. Students recommended the class more to a major and less to a non-major, primarily because of the heavy reading load that was not “unmanageable” as long as you had “a little time management.” Many complained about the heavy reading load and thought that the same material could be taught with less reading.

Through reading texts of Plato (Socrates), Aristotle, Augustine and Aquinas, the student encounters a range of political ideas deeply challenging to--and possibly corrosive of--today's dominant democratic liberalism. Can classical and medieval thinking offer insight into modern impasses in political morality? Is such ancient thinking plausible, useful, or dangerous? 

In general, students “enjoyed the content of the course” and found the class “interesting.” The readings were “a great introduction to classical writing.” However, students noted that lectures could be more “organized.”

Students called Professor Kennedy “knowledgeable” and “passionate” and found lectures “enjoyable.” Students even credited Professor Kennedy with increasing their “interest in political theory.”

Students enjoyed the class and its focus on political science. The work load was described as manageable.

This course examines the political history of the United States through the lens of empire. Beginning with the early settlers and ending with modern presidents, this course surveys major periods of United States history to examine how major political thinkers treated the topic of empire and how the United States conformed to and differed from the definition of an empire. Readings include works from Burke, Paine, as well as presidential speeches, American poets, and foundational documents.

Many students commented that the course content was difficult to pin down. To some students, the readings appeared “random and assigned without rhyme or reason.” Students also criticized Professor Norton’s inclusion of non-introductory material in the class, in particular, references to political theorists not discussed in class or described in readings. Reactions to lectures were mixed. Some students admired the “unorthodox” approach to lecture material, while many described the lectures as simply “disorganized.”

Nearly all students praised Professor Norton’s “exciting” presence. Nevertheless, two broad camps reflected differing opinions of Professor Norton’s teaching style. One large group of students thought that Professor Norton tended “to ramble and get caught in tangents,” which caused difficultly in following the logic of lectures. An equally large group of students, however, considered Professor Norton to be “truly into teaching” and noted that “her excitement about the course material seems to inspire student interest, and she manages to be engaging in spite of the large class size.” 

This introductory course fulfills the Humanities & Social Science sector requirement. Thus, many students appeared to take this class to fulfill the requirement and had no previous background in Political Science. Most students found that they could earn reasonable grades without prior knowledge. Many students found the workload uneven, however, with some weeks requiring “hours of assigned readings” and others, only  “twenty minutes.” Many students also found the assignments to be disconnected from the lectures, and complained that the only midterm fell within a few weeks of the final exam.

This lecture course introduces students to the politics of the Peoples Republic of China. Complementing offerings in other departments, this course emphasizes events in the period since the Chinese Communist Party established its regime in 1949. In addition to surveying the political history of contemporary China, we will assess the meaning of these events by drawing upon theories about the nature and significance of ideology and organization in communist regimes, factionalism and its relationship to policy formulation and implementation, and general issues of political and economic development. Although the principal focus is on the domestic politics of the PRC, the course includes several lectures examining Chinas international relations. 

Many students found this course “enjoyable and informative.” Certain students even claimed that the course had “completely changed” their views of the region and that the “knowledge… gained from this class” will be helpful in the future. The readings were “interesting,” “useful,” and “provide mostly context or supplemental information” to what is taught during lecture.

Professor Goldstein is called “brilliant” and “one of the best professors at Penn.” Professor Goldstein’s lectures were “well-planned, engaging and very interesting.” Additionally, Professor Goldstein frequently e-mailed students “news clips and provided other information related to China.”

The course is “a very enjoyable and informative class, even for a non-political science major.” However, some students commented that “too much emphasis is put on the final exam.”

This course examines the debate in development studies arising from recognition that economic models, theories, methods, and strategies abstracted from the specific experience of western societies and cultures do not have general applicability. A broader social science approach is adopted, one which emphasizes the need to understand the social structures and cultures of the developing countries, the capabilities of weak versus strong states, and the links with the international system that influence transformative processes to which industrializing economies are subjected. The readings offer an overview of the most influential theories of development and underdevelopment that structured debate from the 1960's through the 1990's,and focus on the elements of these approaches that advance understanding of development and stagnation in several key countries, including Brazil, Mexico, India and selected countries in East and Southeast Asia.

Overall, students felt that the course material was “interesting” and “informative.” Despite their appreciation of the content, however, many felt that the presentation was “slightly chaotic” and “unstructured.”

Reactions to Professor Kapur were quite mixed. Some students called him “brilliant,” “engaging” and “very articulate,” while others felt that lectures could me “more stimulating.” Many thought that Professor Kapur’s expectations for the course were far too high, and that this produced a “discouraging learning environment.”

Many students felt that the workload for this course was “unreasonable,” and that it was “simply impossible to keep up” with the assigned readings. One student wrote, “I have written more for this class than any other class I have taken at Penn.” Several, however, still proclaimed this course “one of the best at Penn,” and recommended it to anyone willing to take on the work.

This course is designed to develop your critical reading and writing skills in the areas of international relations and contemporary history. You are expected to take charge of your learning, engaging with each other and the instructor in a process of knowledge creation through practice, inquiry, deliberation, criticism, and problem solving. You will produce three pieces of analytical writing. These are complementary and cumulative assignments that, combined, will enhance your understanding of the nature, purpose, and future of U.S. hegemony or global dominance. This is the issue, arguably, at the core of debate today about US foreign policy or grand strategy. 

The class reads the “five most recent books on American Foreign Policy,” a choice which one student calls a “stroke of genius.” One of the major assignments includes writing book reviews. Students were generally pleased with the course, describing it as “interesting” and one of the “best [courses] I have taken at Penn.” One student remarked that his “favorite part of class was the material” and it consisted of books that he “would read on [his] own.” Other students were enthused by the opportunity to discuss and debate “controversial issues.”

Most students raved about Professor Vitalis’ “unconventional teaching style” which “challenges you” to “think in completely new ways.” He is described as a “dynamic” and “energetic” speaker, as well as being noted for contributing a sense of humor to the class. One student did complain that he brought a “liberal/progressive agenda” to his teaching; though others remarked that he was able to bring up controversial issues without “imposing or even hinting at his own views.”

Students claimed that there was “lots of reading” and that the “method of evaluation – series of critical book reviews” was valuable and enjoyable. The course has no official prerequisites, but it is recommended that a student has taken either PSCI 130 (American Foreign Policy) or PSCI 150 (Introduction to International Relations).

The focus is human rights in global, political, and developmental contexts, especially since 1945. Human rights are part of a wide range of academic disciplines, engineering, history, law, philosophy, and religion being among the obvious. These disciplinary perspectives will be touched upon; politics will be the central one. Some of the main topics include justifications; cross- cultural perspectives; global and international institutional developments and foreign policy. Selected topics will include war, hunger, life, reproduction, servitude, consent, information and the environment. 

In this course students learned a lot about human rights from the abundant amount of reading and the research project. One student reported that he was “glad [he] took the class.” However, many students would have liked to have greater discussion and focus.

Students appreciated that Professor Teune had “very interesting and intelligent things to say about human rights.” However, several students felt the lectures could use a bit more organization.

The course has a hefty amount of reading, a research project, group presentations, and a midterm. Students found it challenging to have group presentations and a midterm in the same week.

This course explores the role of the U.S. Supreme Court in political struggles over the distribution and uses of power in the American constitutional system. Issues include the division of powers between state and national governments, and the branches of the federal government; economic powers of private actors and governmental regulators; the authority of governments to enforce or transform racial and gender hierarchies; and the powers of individuals to make basic choices, such as a woman's power to have an abortion. Special attention is paid to how the tasks of justifying the Supreme Court's own power, and constitutionalism, in general, contribute to logically debatable, but politically powerful constitutional arguments. Readings include Supreme Court decisions and background materials on their historical and political context. 

Many students who took this course described it as “excellent.” Some were surprised that the course focused so heavily on specific cases instead of learning laws, but they found the material interesting, the lectures clear, and the assignments “original.” Some students expressed their hesitation in signing up for the course because of their lack of experience in the field, but found the course to be well taught and were able to “make sense of complicated issues” through lecture. Students also enjoyed the use of clickers in the course as it allowed them to voice opinions, stimulated interaction and fueled discussion. Each student said they were glad they took it. 

There was not a single negative comment about Professor Smith. He was regarded with respect due to his knowledge of the subject as well as praised for his ability to engage students and make lectures entertaining. Many students found his sense of humor to be refreshing and though he was said to fly through material, he always answered questions well. He was also accessible outside of class to answer questions. More than one student said he was the best professor at Penn, “hands down”.

This course should be regarded as challenging but rewarding. The workload was said to be quite heavy and both reading and writing centric. Some students said that not all of the reading was “required” and many lost motivation to read the entire bulk pack throughout the semester. Consequently, some complained this lead to limited student participation in recitation. Overall, the course was recommended to anyone with any remote interest in the subject because of the interesting material and the well-liked professor.

This course provides a broad, humanistic survey to some of the most important ideas, debates, and problems connected to the study of democracy. The course is divided into three segments: the democratic citizen, the democratic People, and the democratic world.

Students were very positive about the content of this course. One student in particular said that it was “extremely interesting and intellectually challenging.” Another student remarked on the “incredible curriculum.” Although there was a lot of assigned reading, the students found that Professor Green did a good job of reviewing it during class.

Students raved about Professor Green. Several hailed him as the best professor they have ever encountered at Penn. One student said Professor Green has “every quality that one looks for in a Professor.” He “cared about what his students learned” and was “always willing to talk after class and during office hours.” The majority of students remarked on his exceptional teaching skills, his ability to effectively communicate a “dense” subject, his talent, and how thought-provoking each lecture was.

Although an upper level Political Science course, several of the students stated that they would recommend this course to all Penn students.

section.name: The Politics of Government in Washington Community

values.comments:
This course intends to familiarize the student with the concept of "law," its use as a constitutive and regulative force in the international arena, and the expanding scope of international law through the inclusion of transnational law and human rights.

Students said the course was “informative” and “thought provoking.” However, some commented that it lacked class discussion time and had minimal student participation.  

Most students praised Professor Fetni for his knowledge of the field. He speaks with “passion” and “confidence” and is able to offer a unique perspective on the materials discussed in class. However, some students said that the lectures were not organized and that there was a lack of control over classroom conduct. Professor Fetni was able to stimulate students’ interest in class, although some wished he would have been more open to different opinions. 

Most students found the workload manageable. This political science course is described as excellent for students with background knowledge in the field. It is also a good course for freshmen, provided they are willing to do extra reading to catch up. This review is based on 6 responses.

This course examines conceptual, explanatory and normative debates over the merits and effectiveness of federations and consociations – and mixed systems. The course evaluates the traits of these systems and why they are formed or attempted, and why they may endure or fail, paying special attention to multi-national, multi-ethnic, multi-religious and multi-lingual environments. The course includes drafting short arguments, a midterm and final exam, a paper, and weekly reading. 

This is a higher-level course so many of the students taking it had some knowledge of the subject already. Therefore, it was recommended that one should only take the course if you already know some background information or are a major. Most students felt that they gained a lot from the course; one student summarized, “I can’t recommend this class enough. It is so worth it”. 

Professor O’Leary was regarded as an expert in his field and a “fantastic” teacher. Students said he was able to communicate the material effectively and clearly and though he often did not lecture on every topic he would always expand on what a group presented. He was described as “approachable” and very willing to discuss the material both inside and outside of the classroom. Some students even reported that O’Leary was their favorite professor at Penn. 

This course has a seminar structure, so the lectures and discussion were cut short to make room for presentations from smaller groups. Some students enjoyed working in small groups and getting to know their fellow classmates, but others would have liked more lecture and time to discuss as a big group. The majority of students reported that they liked how the group activities made them apply their knowledge to real world situations. Students also felt there was a heavy workload of readings, though they increased what students gained from the course.

section.name: Power Sharing in Deeply Divided Places
NEW WRLD ORDER & CRITICS: WSP: New World Order and Its Critics

values.comments:
This is a mandatory seminar for all students planning to submit an honors thesis for the purpose of possibly earning distinction in Political Science upon graduation. The course is aimed at helping students identify a useful and feasible research question, become familiar with the relevant literatures and debates pertaining to that question, develop a basic understanding of what might constitute "good" and "original" research in different subfields, identify a faculty advisor who can supervise the honors thesis, and set up a preliminary plan for conducting and presenting the research. (Note: it is not possible to pre-register for this seminar. All interested students should submit an application for the Honors Program, and students who are accepted into the program will be automatically enrolled in PSCI 497.)

Almost all of the students in this class enjoyed the content. Students found that they had time to discuss their topic of interest with the professor. The whole course was discussion based, which was praised by a lot of the students. However, a small minority of students felt that more time should have been spent on working on the thesis rather than merely talking to the class about it. 

Professor Doherty-Sil received great reviews. She is smart and thought provoking in conducting class discussions. Students commented on her ability to make difficult concepts far more tangible. Professor Doherty-Sil is also “extremely approachable” and “offers great advice” on thesis writing. 

Most students felt that the assessment structure for the thesis paper was sensible. This course is highly recommended to anyone pursuing a political science major. A few students mentioned that there is a large amount of reading for the class.

Consult department for detailed descriptions. More than one course may be taken in a given semester. Typical topics that may be offered include: Political Ideologies of the Non-Western world, Gandhian Thought, and politics of Zionism.

Each student praised this course for its discussion-based focus and felt that they gained a lot from the class. One student called this course his “favorite class at Penn.” Another remarked that the course was “eye opening and thought provoking.”

Students were very positive in their commentary on Professor Doherty-Sil. Several students in particular said she was “excellent,” and another student praised her “constructive feedback on papers and assignments.”

Students noted that there is a lot of assigned reading, and active class participation is expected. The majority of these students were Pre-Law.

This course examines the history and politics of Iraq. Given the disputed nature of the past and present political landscape in Iraq, special attention is given to how and why multiple partisan viewpoints exist in the retelling of Iraq’s history. Course material will work to separate out the influences that shaped modern Iraq and critically examine the documents and other readings.

Students seemed relatively content with the readings and material covered in the course. The course provided excellent background “for those who want to understand what's going on in the Middle East right now.” Although some students found it difficult to complete all the readings for the course, others noted that the course “requires a good deal of commitment to homework and readings” in order to fully benefit from the material.

Students praised Professor O’Leary highly as a leading academic in the field who seemed approachable and willing to help clarify material. Many students thought Professor O’Leary proved “incredibly accommodating in terms of meeting with students.” If any major complaint emerged, it was only that students “would have loved to hear him speak more in this class,” rather than employ so much student presentation and debate. 

Students noted that the coursework seemed to lack a systematic way of distributing assignments. Students also commented that “summaries and debates were too much effort for too little credit.” Some students expressed regret that the class met once a week for three hours rather than meet twice a week for half the time, but most found the class captivating enough to hold their interest.

section.name: The Politics of Iraq and Sudan (1820-2010)
COMP POL HEALTH INEQUAL.: The Comparative Politics of Health Inequalities

values.comments:
Political Science 130 introduces students to the national institutions and political processes of American government. The course examines questions about public policy, while teaching students the basics of American politics and government.

Numerous students described this course as "essentially a civics class." Many students described the readings for this course as "dry" and "overly complex."  

While students reported that Professor Meredith "really knows his stuff," many disliked his tendency to read straight from his lecture slides. 

Many students felt overwhelmed by the amount of reading for this course. Students who enjoyed this course best were those with some background on the subject. Students would not recommend this course for freshmen.

Political Science 135 is an academically based community service seminar that will explore the politics and institutions that have shaped—and continue to shape—food production and consumption. Students will use the readings, their community service, and ongoing "food events" at Penn to analyze the politics of food in many arenas: from farms, kitchens, supermarkets, schools, and communities of faith to corporations, research institutions, the media and international trade.

A majority of students liked and were excited by this “fascinating” class, but were disappointed in the structure of the course. While they felt they learned “quite a lot of thrilling knowledge,” students almost exclusively thought this class was too large and would function better as a smaller seminar. The discussion-based aspect of the class would sometimes “detract” from students’ learning experience, since the class was so large. Furthermore, the class was deemed to have a lot of “busy work,” requiring students to blog for the course. But many students still would recommend this course.

Professor Summers was described as “wonderful, if a bit unorganized.” Students loved the way she conveyed information “clearly” and said she was “definitely knowledgeable about the subject.” She did a great job of “integrating many different views into the course,” but students wished she had structured the class differently so that she was teaching more, rather than relying on peer-led discussions.
