Students were frustrated with having to blog and the disorganized Blackboard site of this class, but overall, they generally enjoyed the course and would recommend it to everyone. This class requires a service project, which students liked, but wish it composed a smaller part of the course.

Political Science 214 discusses the interplay between politics and economics in East Asia. One of the goals of the course is to explain current difficulties of these countries in light of past successes. In addition, the course will consider how the recent growth will illuminate the possibility for long-term success. The first half of the course begins by exploring the causes and consequences of the rise of industrial Asia. The second half of the course examines the challenges to sustained growth faced by many countries in this region in recent years. The course concludes by examining the challenges faced by China and Vietnam today in their attempt to embrace more market-oriented economic systems.

Students enjoyed the course material for the most part. A few mentioned that they appreciated how the graduate and undergraduate sections were separated, yielding a better experience for both parties. A couple students thought the readings were excessive, but there were few complaints on the whole.

A vast majority of students adored Professor Wang. Almost everyone declared him a “great” instructor. While occasionally straying from the course material, he outlined key points thoroughly according to most students. There were no complaints.

The class includes five quizzes, a midterm, and a final. The course is “strongly recommended for majors” of Political Science, according to one evaluator. Some students wished that the professor had done the grading, as they never got to know the TAs. Overall, this course is highly ranked and mostly consists of upperclassmen.

Political Science 252 examines the strategy and politics of warfare, focusing on the way actors plan military campaigns and the factors that are likely to lead to victory and defeat. The course readings center in particular on the factors driving changes in warfare and civil-military relations. The course will cover a wide range of topics from theories of war-fighting to historical military campaigns to insurgency warfare, terrorism, and the future of war.

While most students noted that this class was “tough,” many praised it for its “uniqueness” and thoroughly enjoyed it. The wealth of knowledge offered by this class was said to be both “comprehensible and fascinating in every way.” While students liked the lecture very much, they almost exclusively thought that the amount of reading was “ridiculous” and “unbelievable,” stating that it was “impossible to get through all of the assigned readings.” Students believed that, had the amount of readings been cut down, they would have gotten much more out of this class.

Professor Horowitz was described as “smart, compelling, and approachable,” as well as a “great professor.” He was very forward with his assignments and organized, but he “expected a lot from his students.” He was easily understandable and presented the material in a way that was both “fascinating and exciting.”

Aside from the amount of readings, students remarked that the grading in this class could have been better, with almost the entire grade coming from a single midterm and final. Students expressed that they wished they had a small paper to detract from the weight of the tests.

Political Science 253 addresses the Arab-Israeli dispute from 1948 to the present as a vehicle for understanding how domestic and global political processes interact to shape, contain, or aggravate Middle Eastern wars between states, as well as between states and non-state actors.  Attention is given toward the end of the course to alternative ideas about possible resolution of the conflict as well as to the increasingly prominent argument that, in this case, there is no solution.

Students reported learning a lot from this course. They found the readings to be "interesting" and "thought-provoking."

Students described Professor Lustick as a "dynamic" and "incredible" professor. They appreciated his extensive knowledge and his presentation of the material in "a very objective manner." Students enjoyed going to lectures and found lecture discussion to be "insightful" and "interesting."

Students found this course to be "extremely difficult." There was an extensive amount of reading each week and exams were very hard.

*Political Science 258 focuses on human rights in global, political, and developmental contexts, especially since 1945. Human rights are part of a wide range of academic disciplines, engineering, history, law, philosophy, and religion being among the obvious. These disciplinary perspectives will be touched upon; politics will be the central one. Some of the main topics include justifications; cross-cultural perspectives; global and international institutional developments and foreign policy. Selected topics will include war, hunger, life, reproduction, servitude, consent, information and the environment.

A vast majority of students really loved this “straightforward” and “thought-provoking” class, even if they had no previously experience or interest in global human rights issues. Even though there is a lot of reading for this course, students felt everything was fresh, as the class used lecture, discussion, video clips, and films to help supplement the material. Overall, students believed this course was not very challenging, yet very enjoyable.

Professor Doherty-Sil received unanimously positive reviews from students, being described as “passionate, engaging, friendly, funny, and dedicated.” Furthermore, students believed she was extremely approachable and willing to help if necessary. This “inspiring” professor expects a lot from her students, but students are “happy to do the work” because they believe she “works as hard as her students.”

This course was described as “relatively basic, but fun” and students would recommend it to anyone interested in human rights.

*This review was based on 8 student reviews.

section.name: City Policy: Through the Eyes of New Orleans
The Politics of Government in Washington Community
Power Sharing in Deeply Divided Places
On screen images of American Politics

values.comments:
Philosophy Politics and Economics 202 centers on understanding policymaking. The aims of the course are threefold. Firstly, the framing and description of public problems is discussed. Secondly, the criteria useful in developing and assessing policy choices are examined. Lastly, how policy choices and outcomes are mediated and influenced by individuals, organizations and political institutions is studied. 

A vast majority of students felt that the course was disorganized. Many also noted its resemblance to Introduction to American Political Thought. Multiple other students, however, described the class as “great.” Opinions on the course were mixed.   

Students agreed for the most part that Professor Lapinski was very knowledgeable. A majority of students commented on how quickly he delivered his lectures. A few students labeled his lectures as “dry” and felt that his PowerPoint presentations were a little sparse. One student commented on his insertion of his personal politics into lectures.

PPE considers this class an intermediate course. Some students felt that the readings were either too long or too dense.  There is no final, which led one student to remark that the class felt over two thirds of the way through the semester.

section.name: THE PUBLIC POL PROCESS: The Public Policy Process

values.comments:
Political Science 214 discusses the interplay between politics and economics in East Asia. One of the goals of the course is to explain current difficulties of these countries in light of past successes. In addition, the course will consider how the recent growth will illuminate the possibility for long-term success. The first half of the course begins by exploring the causes and consequences of the rise of industrial Asia. The second half of the course examines the challenges to sustained growth faced by many countries in this region in recent years. The course concludes by examining the challenges faced by China and Vietnam today in their attempt to embrace more market-oriented economic systems.

Students enjoyed the course material for the most part. A few mentioned that they appreciated how the graduate and undergraduate sections were separated, yielding a better experience for both parties. A couple students thought the readings were excessive, but there were few complaints on the whole.

A vast majority of students adored Professor Wang. Almost everyone declared him a “great” instructor. While occasionally straying from the course material, he outlined key points thoroughly according to most students. There were no complaints.

The class includes five quizzes, a midterm, and a final. The course is “strongly recommended for majors” of Political Science, according to one evaluator. Some students wished that the professor had done the grading, as they never got to know the TAs. Overall, this course is highly ranked and mostly consists of upperclassmen.

section.name: Executive Power in Metropolitan American Politics
Executive Power in Metropolitan American Politics
Topics in American Politics and Religion: A Research and Writing Course

values.comments:
The purpose of this freshman seminar is to understand the relationship between business and politics (or between state and capital) in developing countries, the factors which shape this relationship, and their consequences. The seminar analyzes the differences between markets and ownership, the mechanisms by which business and politics influence each other, and the implications for economic growth and equity. Finally, the class will examine the effects of globalization of markets on domestic politics in developing countries. The seminar readings draw upon both conceptual and historical material from a wide range of disciplines and geographical settings.

Students raved about this course. More than one student described it as “the best course I have ever taken at Penn.” Students universally agreed that the class was engaging, saying that it often led to vibrant discussion. The readings were generally regarded as relevant and interesting. Students reported that they gained a great deal of knowledge from the course, with one saying, “I have learned more than I thought possible from a seminar class.”

Students had even better things to say about Professor Kapur, describing him as a “dynamic teacher” with “seemingly endless knowledge.” He reportedly was kind and understanding, willing to offer feedback at any time, and “more of a friend than a professor.” More than one student said Professor Kapur was his/her favorite teacher thus far at Penn.

A student reports that, “We had about 60-80 pages of reading but it was all relevant and made for amazing discussion in class.” Another student recommended the seminar to all freshmen, regardless of prospective major. The workload in the course appeared to be relatively light. The class is designed for freshmen and has no prerequisites. 

*This review is based on the 6 student comments that were submitted.

This course is designed to introduce students to comparative political analysis. How can the political behavior, circumstances, institutions, and dynamic patterns of change that people experience in very different societies be analyzed using the same set of concepts and theories? Key themes include nationalism, political culture, democratization, authoritarianism, and the nature of protracted conflict.

Students had mixed opinions on the content of the course. Some found it “interesting” and “relevant,” and others felt it was “broad and dated.” Many concurred that it was “a good introductory course for political science.”

Many felt that Professor Lynch “read directly from her slides” and was “unwilling to answer questions.” Some thought Professor Lynch was a “great professor” and “enthusiastic,” but many others commented that she treated students “like children.”

Students on the whole did not find this course too challenging. However, many commented that there was not “adequate time for comprehensive essays” on exams, and students often “ran out of time.” Students agreed that material could be “easily understood by a non-major.” This course fulfills the Society sector requirement.

This course analyzes the formation and conduct of foreign policy in the United State. The course combines three elements: a study of the history of American foreign relations, an analysis of the causes of American foreign policy such as the international system, public opinion, and the media, and a discussion of the major policy issues in contemporary U.S. foreign policy, including terrorism, civil wars, and economic policy.
Students claimed that this was their favorite IR class. They loved the material covered in the class; they found the lectures and readings “stimulating” and “interesting."

Students heaped praised upon Professor Horowitz. One described his teaching style as “clear” and “straight-forward”. 

This course is meant for both majors and non-majors alike. Even though some people thought there was too much reading, most found the readings very interesting and relevant to the course.

section.name: International Relations in Theory and Practice

values.comments:
This course provides an overview of major figures and themes of modern political thought, particularly focusing on the relationship of the individual to community, society, and state. The course considers the political forms that emerged out of the struggles of this relationship, as well as the changed and distinctly "modern" conceptualizations of political theory such as freedom, responsibility, justice, rights and obligations, as central categories for organizing moral and political life.
Many students commented that although this class was interesting, the lectures were often “disjointed, disorganized, and freewheeling.” The recitations for this class, however, were found to be not only informative, but also very helpful.
Prof. Norton was described by students as an “animated lecturer”, exuding “an energy that is inspiring.” Nevertheless, even her biggest fans agreed that she “tended to go on tangents minimally related to the topic.” Although some students thought that these extra anecdotes gave the class a “broader relevance,” most objected to the musings.
Students recommended this course as an excellent foundational class for all political science majors, but warned that the reading assignments were extensive and time-consuming. PSCI 181 fulfills the History and Tradition Sector.

This course is an introduction to the most prominent historical, cultural, institutional, and ideological features of Middle Eastern politics. Typical of the questions we shall address are why processes of modernization and economic change have not produced liberal democracies, why Islamic movements have gained enormous strength in some countries and not others, why conflicts in the region--between Israel and the Arabs, Iran and Iraq, or inside of Lebanon--have been so bitter and protracted; why the era of military coups was brought to an end but transitions to democracy have been difficult to achieve; why Arab unity has been so elusive and yet so insistent a theme; and why oil wealth in the Gulf, in the Arabian Peninsula, and in North Africa, has not produced industrialization or self-sustaining economic growth. By careful consideration of recent scholarly research on Middle Eastern politics students will gain an appreciation for the special challenges, opportunities, and responsibilities associated with systematic analysis of politics in a comparative setting.
Students who took the class agreed that Professor Vitalis generally followed the syllabus and course description.

Reviews were mixed regarding the lecture style. Some students described the discussion-heavy format as engaging and conducive to Professor Vitalis’ “unique” style. Others found that the “attempt to run a medium-sized lecture as a seminar was at times very frustrating,” leading to a class that could feel “unstructured.” A number of students were very impressed with Professor Vitalis, noting that he “does an excellent job of communicating important and complex subject matter,” and that he is “lively and entertaining.”

Students’ main criticisms pertained to the assignments, with many finding the critical book reviews difficult and strictly graded, considering the class “focused little on how exactly to write a book review.” On the other hand, some felt that the assignments were very helpful in improving critical writing skills. A few students noted that this class is so worthwhile that it should be considered “a must” for political science majors interested in the Middle East.

By examining Supreme Court decisions in light of works on American history, politics, and political theory, this class will explore legal, political, and philosophical debates on civil liberties today. Readings will consider litigation of the 1st, 2nd, 4th, 5th, 8th, and 14th Amendments. Issues will include struggles over freedom of religion, speech, privacy, and property rights, analyzed in the context of American cultural traditions and hierarchies along with conflicts over the rights of suspects, criminals and citizens, analyzed in the context of racial and class tensions, criminal violence, and anti-terrorist security.

Overall, students found this class very interesting. Students really enjoyed the lectures because Professor Smith tied together the information in different Supreme Court cases very well. In addition, he always tied what they were learning to current events and how they related to what was being taught. 
Students heaped praise on Professor Smith. One student claimed he was “hilarious and down-to-earth.” Most students said he was a very accessible teacher and did a great job connecting material from different lectures. 
The class is recommended for both majors and non-majors alike. Students found the work load very manageable. The assessments consisted of a three-page paper, a midterm, and either a final

This course surveys the institutional development of the American presidency from the Constitutional Convention through the current administration. It examines the politics of presidential leadership, and how the executive branch functions. An underlying theme of the course is the tension between the presidency, leadership, and democracy.

Students generally had positive feelings about the content of the course. For the most part, they agreed that both the lecture and readings were interesting and relevant. Many students mentioned that they “learned a lot” from the course. However, a few students expressed discontent with the consistent slant of the readings. One stated the following: “Readings could have been more balanced, since most [came] blatantly from the left wing.”

Professor Gottschalk was relatively well-liked by the students, being described as a “very good” and “devoted” lecturer. Students praised the fact that she was “always willing to stop and answer student questions.” One student relates that Gottschalk is one of the “nicest professors” at Penn, while another lauds her sharp sense of humor.

Students considered the course to be somewhat difficult, with a decent workload. One student complained that the two large papers were “graded rather harshly.” Another student registered a complaint about being forced to buy and carry a bulk pack of books, saying this “made the reading more of a chore.” On the other hand, most other students had no such complaints, and the level of difficulty appears reasonable. The course was open to all students, with no prerequisites.

section.name: Pop Culture: Islam in the West
WSP: Representation in American Politics - Berkeley - David Karol
WSP: Political Reform - Berkeley - Bruce Cain
WSP: Environmental Policymaking - Univ of Michigan - Kathy Wagner
Inside/Out: The Politics of Crime and Punishment

values.comments:
This seminar places the concept of leadership in its historical and civic context. It explores competing contemporary social science theories and related empirical research on “leadership.” It involves intensive case-based analysis, interviews with “leaders” from diverse sectors, and site-based projects conducted by student task groups.

Students had very positive feelings about the course, describing it as “great” and “fantastic.” Students generally seemed to view the course content as interesting and applicable to their own lives. Time was reportedly equally split between discussion and lecture. One student gushes: “I can honestly say that [this] class fundamentally changed my outlook for the better.”

Students repeatedly described Professor DiIulio as one of the best professors at Penn, praising him for his passionate lectures and empathy for students. Nearly all of the reviews that were submitted heaped praise upon DiIulio. He is reportedly a “captivating” and “unbelievable” lecturer. A student claims the following: “Stories of John DiIulio’s teaching prowess are not exaggerated.”

Very few complaints were registered about the workload. The course seemed to be regarded as not too difficult, with a reasonable amount of work. The class features guest speakers and is heavy on personal development. One student reported that the course was a “bit reading intensive” but goes on to say that the readings were both interesting and useful. There are no prerequisites for the course.

section.name: MLA Proseminar: Oil, Politics and Culture

values.comments:
This course provides an overview of major figures and themes of modern political thought, particularly focusing on the relationship of the individual to community, society, and state. The course considers the political forms that emerged out of the struggles of this relationship, as well as the changed and distinctly "modern" conceptualizations of political theory such as freedom, responsibility, justice, rights and obligations, as central categories for organizing moral and political life.
Many students commented that although this class was interesting, the lectures were often “disjointed, disorganized, and freewheeling.” The recitations for this class, however, were found to be not only informative, but also very helpful.
Prof. Norton was described by students as an “animated lecturer”, exuding “an energy that is inspiring.” Nevertheless, even her biggest fans agreed that she “tended to go on tangents minimally related to the topic.” Although some students thought that these extra anecdotes gave the class a “broader relevance,” most objected to the musings.
Students recommended this course as an excellent foundational class for all political science majors, but warned that the reading assignments were extensive and time-consuming. PSCI 181 fulfills the History and Tradition Sector.

This course analyzes the formation and conduct of foreign policy in the United State. The course combines three elements: a study of the history of American foreign relations; an analysis of the causes of American foreign policy such as the international system, public opinion, and the media; and a discussion of the major policy issues in contemporary U.S. foreign policy, including terrorism, civil wars, and economic policy.
	This course was described as “very interesting” by many students, and it seemed that all had a positive opinion of it. Material was interesting and presented in a “compelling way.” Students noted that there was an “enormous amount of reading,” but many also noted that the reading was interesting and helpful. Some students found studying for tests hard, as ID terms were often only mentioned once in class.
	Students were enthralled by Professor Horowitz, who was described as an “excellent professor,” a “great guy,” and a “captivating lecturer.” He was praised unanimously as being enthusiastic and passionate about the material. 
	Students felt very strongly about this course, offering unanimous praise, and noting that they wanted to learn more about the material due to the professor. There was a lot of required reading, but many students found it helpful.

This lecture course introduces students to the subfield of international security or strategic studies.  In order to grasp the usefulness of the theoretical ideas presented in readings and lectures, abstract concepts are linked with a study of the national security policies states have adopted in the decades following World War II.  Topics include current debates about nuclear proliferation, terrorism, the Iraq war and Europe's changing international role.

Although some students mentioned that it was an “excellent course” and “the course taught me a lot about the history and theory of security strategy which will definitely help me going forward in my political science work,” most other students commented that they “disliked this course greatly” and “the course reading for the first half of the course could have been a lot more interesting.” 

The reviews were generally very positive for Professor Goldstein. Students commented on his exceptional lecturing skills. One student mentioned that “Avery Goldstein is a commendable professor,” and another stated that he is “extremely knowledgeable, communicates material well, [and] facilitates a lecture environment conducive to learning and understanding the material.”

One student mentioned, “this course is a must-take for students that want to understand today's globalized political environment.” It is also highly recommended for students wishing to major or minor in international relations or similar majors. The course load consists of lots of readings, and the lectures may move relatively fast to cover all of the material needed. There are no prerequisites for this class.

This course examines the politics of international economic relations. The course will analyze the interplay between politics and economics in three broad areas: international trade, international finance, and economic development. In each section, we will first discuss economic theories that explain the causes and consequences of international commerce, capital flows, and economic growth. We will then explore how political interests, institutions, and ideas alter these predictions, examining both historical examples and current policy debates.
	Students felt that the powerpoint slides and the textbook made the material “very clear,” and also felt that the course material was interesting unto itself. However, some students felt that the exams were too focused on “minutia from the assigned readings” and did not accurately test knowledge of the course material. The course was overall described as “interesting but a little boring,” a sentiment that many students seemed to share.  Another student noted that only “1/3 of the class attends lecture.”
	Professor Gray was criticized as a below-average professor: students felt that she “makes the material less interesting than it actually is.” Other students noted that Professor Gray seemed to “care more about her research than her students,” and some faulted her for not being flexible enough when it came to student requests.
 	Students were interested by the course material, but not thrilled with Professor Gray. The exams were described as somewhat difficult, but otherwise the workload was not commented upon.

This course discusses an America founded in resistance to empire. In the generations between, Americans have desired, dreaded and debated empire. This course will focus on empire and imperialism in American political thought. Students will read primary texts addressing empire: from the departure and dissent of the Puritans, and Burke's Speech on Conciliation with the Colonies, to twentieth and twenty-first century debates over America's role in the world. These texts will include political pamphlets and speeches, poetry, novels, policy papers and film.
	Many students felt that the material covered in the course did not match the above description. The course was described as “boring” and one student reported that “it was hard to get myself to go to class.” Students felt that the grading was often unfair, as they were not graded by their own TA, and was therefore “wildly inconsistent.”
	Professor Hirschmann was faulted for her “obvious political views” and for turning the course into a “liberal studies / gender studies course.” Students described her as frequently “unprepared” as well as disorganized. Hirschmann was also faulted for leaving her students “high and dry” before the final, not offering any review sessions or such.
	Students were rather disappointed with this class. One student expressed disbelief that he needed to take this course for his major. The papers were described as being graded unfairly, and the students did not enjoy Professor Hirschmann’s lecture style or coverage of the material.

section.name: The European Union: Arguments and Evidence

values.comments:
This course surveys the institutional development of the American presidency from the Constitutional convention through the current administration.  It examines the politics of presidential leadership, and how the executive branch functions.  An underlying theme of the course is the tensions between the presidency, leadership, and democracy.

Almost every student agreed that this course required “more work than any of their other classes at Penn” but that it was by far the “most enjoyable and most rewarding.” Students seemed to understand that they would be required to work hard before coming into the class, but definitely felt that this was “one of the best courses they’ve taken at Penn.” The required readings and papers take up a lot of time, but a majority of students said that the time spent was “almost always pleasant.”

Professor Gottschalk was said to “command attention” in her classroom. A vast majority of students felt that she “had very high expectations” but was very knowledgeable and accessible to her students. She “stimulated student interest” and “challenged previously held viewpoints.” Almost all of the reviews of Professor Gottschalk were resoundingly positive.

Although this course requires a lot of work, many students felt it was worthwhile to take, even if you aren’t a Poli-sci major. Professor Gottschalk doesn’t allow electronics in her classroom and students felt that this policy helped the class interact with each other more.

section.name: WSP: U.S. FOREIGN POLICY AND THE MIDDLE EAST
THE POL OF EDUCATION: WSP: THE POLITICS OF EDUCATION
WSP: POLITICAL REFORM: WSP: BERKELEY - POLITICAL REFORM

values.comments:
Consult department for detailed descriptions.  Recent topics include: Globalization; Race & Criminal Justice; Democracy & Markets in Post-Communist Europe.

Students mentioned that “the material was very interesting and thought provoking.” It was an “awesome class” and “genuinely enjoyable.” However, one student mentioned that the “use of computer simulations has not been productive.” Overall, the course received positive comments, and was described as “intellectually rewarding.”

Professor Narang received very positive comments. He was described as “an amazing professor” and he “really moved discussions and got the entire class critiquing, questioning, and defending the readings.” He was also “very knowledgeable” and “qualified.”

This course is described as having a very specific focus and one student expressed that “one possible concern in this class was that it was too easy for a 498 PSCI seminar.” There is a “journal club” component which involves two people leading class discussions. There are some readings that are assigned. There are no prerequisites for this course.

section.name: POLITICS OF IRAQ & SUDAN: The Politics of Iraq and Sudan (1820-2010)
COMPARATIVE POL COMM: Comparative Political Communication

values.comments:
This course explores the role of communication in theories of political change and democratic development.  It addresses the questions: What are the major hypotheses about the relationship between communication and regime type?  How have our hypotheses about communication evolved over time in response to changes in prominent development theories, policy trends, technical developments, and empirical evidence? 

Overall, this course was described as being interesting and insightful to an extent. Students said the topics discussed in the course were “valuable and interesting overall but a little onerous.” Many students remarked that the final project was “annoying,” but that it was a “great learning curve.” Some also stated that the readings were very relevant to the topics they were studying in the class, but that they tended to become repetitive as the class developed. Overall, most of the students enjoyed the readings and the class discussions.

The majority of students in the class felt that Professor Moehler could do a better job of teaching in class. One student mentioned that she “was good one on one, especially in office hours.” However, some students stated that “in class she wasn’t very engaging,” and “needs to do a better job of facilitating discussion,” because they could often go off-topic, which would waste valuable class time. One student also mentioned that she was very micromanaging on the research paper.

The course is composed of a lot of reading and a final research paper. There are frequent class discussions meant to involve participation. One student mentioned that the course was “a fantastic introduction to the study of democracy within the purview of Comparative Politics.” This course is designed for Benjamin Franklin Scholars. There are no other prerequisites for this course.
